data.text: LIVE: #FiscalMonitor press briefing on how fiscal policy can play a key role in fostering a strong, inclusive, and green recovery from the pandemic. https://t.co/rzMw52yxwV #IMFmeetings https://t.co/3papswHCue

The October 2020 #FiscalMonitor examines how governments are managing the crisis, and discusses what they can do to save lives, mitigate the impact of the recession, and revive growth and job creation. https://t.co/ZooX4v4RiE https://t.co/IpFgdzQrtJ

LIVE: #FiscalMonitor press briefing on how fiscal policy can play a key role in fostering a strong, inclusive, and green recovery from the pandemic. https://t.co/rzMw52yxwV #IMFmeetings https://t.co/3papswHCue

The global economy is recovering from the #COVID19 pandemic but the long ascent back to growth is uneven and uncertain. Find out more in our latest World Economic Outlook #WEO https://t.co/XMCO1emJHw https://t.co/CsWwch7eop

The recovery for the global economy will likely be long, uneven, and uncertain, with some economies starting to recover faster than anticipated, and some seeing worsening prospects. See projections by region. #IMFBlog #WEO https://t.co/XMCO1emJHw https://t.co/wC8ajL9KZk
🆕 Latest growth projections for the global economy and for countries in the October 2020 World Economic Outlook #WEO. #IMFBlog https://t.co/ZpkEgqFQHK https://t.co/FgNk2SlRxr

📅 SAVE THE DATE: Oct. 15 at 12:00pm EDT, for the upcoming #IMFmeetings debate on the global economy with @KGeorgieva, @smindrawatii, @NOIweala, moderated by @CNBC @GeoffCutmore https://t.co/9AIQHNRxk7 #GlobalEcon https://t.co/ngKXBmeqj3
[REPLAY] World Economic Outlook Press Briefing. https://t.co/Lg4X4jcRe3 #WEO https://t.co/QfY3OWyi04

IMF Deputy Managing Director Antoinette Sayeh at the Virtual Global Parliamentary Forum 2020: “Gender-responsive policies are growth-enhancing policies” https://t.co/yVM4v0nzQA #IMFGender #GenderEquality https://t.co/pt6ORTE5ug

The exceptional policy response, including the creation of the #EU pandemic recovery fund & the use of digital technologies to deliver social assistance are a powerful reminder that well-designed policies protect people & collective economic wellbeing. https://t.co/ZpkEgqFQHK https://t.co/sZ9m16KWGQ

This is the worst crisis since the Great Depression. It will take significant innovation on the policy front, at both the national & international levels to recover from this calamity.  The challenges are daunting. But there are reasons to be hopeful. #WEO https://t.co/ZpkEgqFQHK
ICYMI: Watch the presentation on the October 2020 Global Financial Stability Report https://t.co/dZF5bRbCSy #GFSR https://t.co/8VyGyyBh4X

IMF’s Tao Zhang at the launch of the Development Data Partnership—a new data sharing model bringing the IMF, @WorldBank, @the_IDB & companies together so that policies for the public good can be informed by private sector data. https://t.co/DiWk50wwyY https://t.co/ft8guDeG28 https://t.co/lok0nj3SiZ

Governments should do all that they can to combat the health crisis and mitigate the deep downturn while being ready to adjust policy strategy as the pandemic and its impact on activity evolve. Read our latest #WEO: https://t.co/XMCO1emJHw https://t.co/9NPNkoiliu

For many countries, sustaining economic activity and helping individuals & firms in need—while ensuring that debt remains sustainable—is a daunting task, given high public debt, the spending needs triggered by the crisis, and the hit to public revenues. #WEO

How do we pave the way for an #inclusiverecovery? @melindagates + @KGeorgieva discuss the need for investments—in testing, therapeutics, and vaccines—as well as global cooperation to overcome #COVID19. w/ @BeckyCNN Oct 14 @12:30 pm ET

▶️Watch LIVE here: https://t.co/0jZJ5bBEcL https://t.co/EGV43RtsOZ

Gender-responsive policies are growth-enhancing policies. IMF Deputy Managing Director Antoinette Sayeh, @WorldBank’s @Mari_Pangestu and #parliamentarians from around the world discuss building a better recovery that achieves both growth and #genderequality. #IMFmeetings

The #COVID19 crisis will deal a severe blow to global output compared to pre-pandemic projections, holding back living standard improvements across all countries, the latest IMF World Economic Outlook shows. #IMFBlog https://t.co/ZpkEgqFQHK https://t.co/EoP1B47OGK
📊 NEW: See the latest global, regional, and country projections in the October issue of the World Economic Outlook #WEO. https://t.co/ZpkEgqFQHK https://t.co/yKGPpr181r

The global easing of financial conditions helped stabilize most emerging markets’ access to financing & lower the volatility of their capital flows. However, some low-income countries face imminent debt distress due to high borrowing costs. https://t.co/xkh9Ro3zeO #GFSR #IMFBlog https://t.co/X90jdDihMU

In the latest issue of the World Economic Outlook, IMF Chief Economist Gita Gopinath says the recession will continue in 2020 with global growth projected at -4.4% and a partial rebound to 5.2% growth in 2021. Read the #WEO report. https://t.co/XMCO1emJHw https://t.co/uwF3SXc79G

Besides combating the deep near-term recession, policymakers have to address complex challenges to place economies on a path of higher productivity growth while ensuring that gains are shared evenly and debt remains sustainable. Read the latest #WEO. https://t.co/XMCO1emJHw https://t.co/k6vxkCEJNV

A sustained recovery will require global health cooperation, policies to limit long-lasting damage, and an eye toward placing economies on paths of stronger, equitable, and sustainable growth. Read our latest #WEO. #IMFBlog  https://t.co/ZpkEgqFQHK https://t.co/fpZIzd4Ctt
Read the latest statement by the #G24 here: https://t.co/ykk49w74xO https://t.co/Le60ptIRqy

LIVE: @KGeorgieva, UN’s Special Envoy for #ClimateAction Mark Carney, @blackrock’s Laurence Fink and Angola’s Finance Minister Vera Daves de Sousa, alongside moderator @flacqua discuss how countries should #BuildForwardBetter. https://t.co/WmcWRnElEt https://t.co/HQeSj49kHk

LIVE: @KGeorgieva, UN’s Special Envoy for #ClimateAction Mark Carney, @blackrock’s Laurence Fink and Angola’s Finance Minister Vera Daves de Sousa, alongside moderator @flacqua discuss how countries should #BuildForwardBetter. https://t.co/WmcWRnElEt https://t.co/HQeSj49kHk

Policymakers face a choice between the much needed support now and the potential stability risks it creates down the road, and need to closely monitor the potential consequences of this unprecedented support. https://t.co/ipn0Ws4Llc #GFSR #IMFBlog

Our latest #GFSR research shows that massive monetary and fiscal support across the globe have helped contain financial stability risks for now, despite the biggest recession since the Great Depression. https://t.co/T24KOjYZu2 https://t.co/Hbr6aO8NOT

Policy support has allowed the corporate sector to address liquidity pressures by increasing borrowing; but as their debts reach unprecedented levels, firms become much more vulnerable https://t.co/AfSBP0P79J #GFSR #IMFBlog https://t.co/e004VCGqoy

The significant improvement in market sentiment has helped maintain the flow of credit, but we are concerned about the disconnect between financial markets and the uncertain evolution of the economy. https://t.co/31p9mkn5fz #IMFBlog https://t.co/UVMOjiSiKa

STARTING NOW: Live press conference on the release of the October 2020 Global Financial Stability Report by IMF Financial Counsellor Tobias Adrian. Read the report: https://t.co/2gBlXRxZiK #GFSR https://t.co/8VyGyyjFGn

Growth in the #advancedeconomies group is projected at –5.8% in 2020, 2.3 percentage points stronger than in the June 2020 WEO Update reflecting better-than-foreseen #US and #euroarea GDP growth. Read more in the #WEO https://t.co/XMCO1e58iW https://t.co/eL0MkNEA0i

For #emergingmarket and developing economies, growth is forecast at –3.3% in 2020, 0.2 percentage point weaker than in the June 2020 WEO Update, strengthening to 6% in 2021. Read the latest #WEO. https://t.co/XMCO1e58iW https://t.co/4dsfMO2neO

The recovery from the #COVID19 crisis will be long, uneven and highly uncertain. The global economy is forecasted to remain in a deep recession in 2020 with real GDP growth at -4.4%. See our latest projections in the October 2020 #WEO. #IMFBlog https://t.co/ZpkEgqFQHK https://t.co/Gxn657NBIb

For China, the benefits of getting to net zero emissions would be among the highest in the world –– about 1% of GDP now and 3.5% of GDP around 2050. Read our latest #WEO research: https://t.co/XMCO1emJHw #ClimateChange https://t.co/0c0zSeCi7O

Our latest research finds that #lockdowns involve short-term economic costs but may pave the way to a faster recovery by containing the spread of the virus & reducing voluntary social distancing over time. Read our new #WEO chapter: https://t.co/XMCO1emJHw #COVID19 https://t.co/UitChQM6PA

Lockdown measures to contain #COVID19 had a disproportional impact on women and young people, according to IMF analysis of real-time data. Targeted policies are necessary to avoid widening inequality. #IMFBlog #WEO https://t.co/7KncWPHYmt https://t.co/77RW4SMkd5

The UN’s World Food Programme, recipient of the 2020 Nobel Peace Prize, projects that 270 million people will go hungry in countries where it operates before the end of the year, 82% more than before the pandemic. Learn more in F&D magazine: https://t.co/pgqUUgHP4u #NobelPrize https://t.co/5z4u3Td4ZX

Pairing #carbontaxes and policies to cushion higher energy costs for vulnerable consumers can rapidly reduce emissions & avert a rise in global temperatures. IMF research shows this can be done without negative impacts on employment & growth. #IMFBlog #WEO https://t.co/rbOh3DL55Q https://t.co/K0wCmM57XZ

Green stimulus, gradually rising carbon prices and compensation for vulnerable households can reduce emissions to net zero by 2050 while boosting the recovery. Read our latest #WEO research on #climatechange https://t.co/XMCO1emJHw https://t.co/N5JOLDqlGG
